document_title: Systemic lupus erythematosus: Causes, symptoms, treatment and prevention
subsection_name: lupus-ban-do-he-thong.json_11_Frequently asked questions about lupus erythematosus
subsection_content:
Is lupus erythematosus contagious?
Lupus erythematosus is a non-contagious disease. You cannot catch it from another person even through very close contact or sexual intercourse. Experts believe that this autoimmune disease begins due to a combination of genes, environment and endocrine in the body.
Is lupus erythematosus dangerous?
This is a dangerous disease because its damage appears in many tissues and organs of the body and currently there is no specific medicine to treat the disease. According to current research, more than 5 million people in the world are affected by this disease and 16,000 people are newly diagnosed each year. The disease affects the skin, joints, heart, lungs, and kidneys; causing damage to the entire body. The case of pop singer Selena Gomez is a typical example of a patient with severe lupus erythematosus when she had to undergo an organ transplant to treat the disease.
Although it is a dangerous disease like lupus erythematosus, it is difficult to diagnose. To prevent disease, if you feel you have the symptoms described above, you should go to specialized medical facilities for examination and diagnosis.
Is lupus erythematosus hereditary?
Researchers have found more than 50 genes that they believe are involved in the condition. These genes are more commonly found in people with lupus than in people without the disease. Most of these genes have not been shown to directly cause lupus, but they are believed to contribute to the disease.
Can lupus erythematosus have children?
Women with lupus erythematosus can safely become pregnant if the disease is controlled. Therefore, you will need to start planning your pregnancy well before you get pregnant.
Patients should be in control or in remission for six months before pregnancy. Pregnancy with active lupus can lead to miscarriage, stillbirth, or other serious health problems for yourself or your baby.; Pregnancy is risky for certain groups of women with lupus including women with high blood pressure, lung disease, heart failure, chronic renal failure, kidney disease, or a history of preeclampsia.
If you are a lupus patient and want to start planning a pregnancy, you should talk to your doctor to be best prepared before getting pregnant. In addition, find an obstetrician with experience caring for and treating women with lupus for advice.
Does lupus erythematosus itch?
Because it is a disease with a rash on the skin, many people wonder if lupus erythematosus will itch. However, most patients with lupus erythematosus do not feel itchy, or have very little itching.
